body:
It's working for me. Can you reproduce in a codesandbox, please?

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2339362/86651288-c7ca4b80-bfb9-11ea-8771-b4b5a8c98ce3.png)

Yes, reproduced in CodeSandbox: https://codesandbox.io/s/react-testing-library-demo-3c133?file=/src/__tests__/hello.js

it works fine if it was the only style property. When there are more, it gives false-positive. I also updated the original issue description

I don't understand, why we need to serialize styles to string and then parse it back, losing the information about empty but defined keys.

The color normalization is being done later in [another function](https://github.com/testing-library/jest-dom/blob/7ea936d62cfda3aaa6f4ee9a2b7a0aa576e2e55a/src/to-have-style.js#L10-L14), why `parseCSS` is needed for object syntax?

I don't know if I got your question, but we need to normalize the expected value to match it against the element's css.

An element with the style `background-color: red; min-width: 200px` has to match against both `toHaveStyle`s (no matter what is the order):
```
expect(element).toHaveStyle('min-width: 200px; background-color: red')
expect(element).toHaveStyle({ minWidth: '200px', backgroundColor: 'red' })
```

One function converts styled css in css text, another parses the css text in object like `{ background-color }` to match it against the element's `computedStyle`.

Yes, parsing CSS makes sense for the CSS-as-string argument. However, for the object format, it seems redundant, because keys order usually does not affect object equality.

Is there a chance to refactor `toHaveStyle` implementation to make it just like `expect(element.style).toEqual({...})` with extra colors normalization?
I got your point. I think it could work. Do you want to try it?
Yes, I will give it a try and come back with a PR if this works out.

issue.title: fix(toHaveStyle): strictly match empty values

repository.name: jest-dom
repository.description: :owl: Custom jest matchers to test the state of the DOM

issue.body:
**What**:

fixes the issue #272

**Why**:

Current implementation allows false positive matches. More examples in the linked issue

issue.title: toHaveStyle doesn't take account of CSS custom properties

repository.name: jest-dom
repository.description: :owl: Custom jest matchers to test the state of the DOM

issue.body:
- `@testing-library/jest-dom` version: 5.1.1 - `node` version: 12.16.2 - `npm` (or `yarn`) version: 1.22.4 ### Relevant code or config: ```js test.only('failing test', () => { const style = document.createElement('style') style.innerHTML = ` div { --color: blue; } ` const {container} = render(`
Hello world
`) document.body.appendChild(style) document.body.appendChild(container) expect(container).toHaveStyle(`--color: blue`) }) ``` ### Problem description: If you were to run the test above, this would fail because `toHaveStyle` doesn't take account of CSS custom properties. ### Suggested solution: I think the PR #276 caused this behavior. Indeed, the `isSubset` function has been changed and doesn't use `getPropertyValue` anymore (see [this line](https://github.com/testing-library/jest-dom/pull/276/files#diff-4e1129d165c9efdd245d6f1726948bbbL24)). It seems a custom property on [`CSSStyleDeclaration`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CSSStyleDeclaration) can't be accessed simply using the property key (for example `computedStyle['--color']`), you explicitely have to use [`getPropertyValue`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CSSStyleDeclaration/getPropertyValue). I forked the repo and changed back the `isSubset` function to use `getPropertyValue` and things work well. That may be a solution (I assume there's a reason why it's been changed so things may not be so simple).
